case_vignette:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive intermittent pain and swelling in both knees and right ankle and wrist for 3 months. She has been taking acetaminophen and using ice packs, both of which relieved her symptoms. The affected joints feel ""stuck” and difficult to move when she wakes up in the morning, but she can move them freely after a few minutes. She has also occasional mild eye pain that resolves spontaneously. Five months ago she was diagnosed with upper respiratory tract infection that resolved without treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows that the affected joints are swollen, erythematous, and tender to touch. Slit-lamp examination shows an anterior chamber flare with signs of iris inflammation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.6 g/dl
Leukocyte count 8,000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 76%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 3%
Platelet count 360,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 36 mm/hr
Serum
Antinuclear antibodies 1:320
Rheumatoid factor negative
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having pain and swelling in both my knees and my right ankle and wrist that comes and goes, and sometimes I feel stiffness in these joints when I wake up.
Have you noticed any joint pain or stiffness in other parts of your body?
No, just in my knees, right ankle, and wrist.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist for more than three months?
Yes, the pain and swelling have been going on for 3 months.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has worsened over the past month?
The pain and swelling have been getting progressively worse over the past 3 months.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by fever or chills?
No, I haven't had fever or chills with the joint pain and stiffness.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by fatigue or weakness?
I haven't mentioned feeling fatigued or weak.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by morning stiffness?
Yes, the joints feel "stuck" and difficult to move when I wake up.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by a rash or redness?
The affected joints are swollen and red.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by a history of autoimmune disease?
I haven't mentioned any history of autoimmune disease.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by a family history of autoimmune disease?
I haven't mentioned any family history of autoimmune disease.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by a history of blood clots?
I haven't mentioned having a history of blood clots.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by a history of cancer?
I haven't mentioned having a history of cancer.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by a history of infections?
I was diagnosed with an upper respiratory tract infection five months ago.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by a history of gout?
I haven't mentioned having a history of gout.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in your knees, ankle, or wrist that has been accompanied by a history of osteoarthritis?

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The patient reports experiencing pain and swelling in both knees, as well as in the right ankle and wrist, for the past 3 months. The pain and swelling have been progressively worsening during this time. There is also stiffness in these joints upon waking up in the mornings. The affected joints appear swollen and red, and feel "stuck" and difficult to move when waking up. The patient denies any fever, chills, fatigue, or weakness associated with the joint pain and stiffness. Additionally, there is no history of autoimmune disease, family history of autoimmune disease, blood clots, cancer, or gout. The patient was diagnosed with an upper respiratory tract infection five months ago.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (SJIA).
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).
trial_0.multiturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The most likely diagnosis is rheumatoid arthritis.
